title: Typhoon Hagibis: Woman dropped 40 metres from rescue helicopter
text:
More than 27,000 military troops and other aid personnel have been been deployed to help with the aftermath of Typhoon Hagibis (Picture: AP/Getty)

More than 27,000 military troops have been deployed to help rescue people trapped in floods after ferocious Typhoon Hagibis caused devastation across Japan.

The death toll, from the worst storm to hit mainland Japan in 60 years, currently stands at 19 with more than a dozen people missing.

It includes a women in her 70s who was dropped 40 metres to the ground while she was being airlifted into a rescue helicopter in Iwaki city, Fukushima, about 120 miles north east of Tokyo.

She was taken to hospital but later died from her injuries.

Authorities have also warned of the dangers posed by mudslides with those buried in landslides among the dead. Other fatalities include people swept away by raging rivers.

Cabinet minister Yoshihide Suga said recovery was on its way to help the 376,000 homes without electricity, and 14,000 homes with no running water.

Across Japan helicopters and boats were deployed today to rescue people stranded in flooded homes with the public broadcaster NHK saying that 14 rivers have flooded following torrential rains and 100mph winds.

Evacuation warnings have been sent out to more than six million people with tens of thousands seeking refuge in emergency centres in coastal towns.

Mr Suga said: ‘The major typhoon has caused immense damage far and wide in eastern Japan.’

The Tama River, which runs by Tokyo, spilled its banks, flooding homes and other buildings in the area.

Residential areas are submerged in muddy waters after an embankment of the Chikuma River, left, broke because of Typhoon Hagibis, in Nagano (Picture: AP/ Kyodo News)

Residents clean up a flooded street in the aftermath of Typhoon Hagibis in Kawasaki (Picture: JIJI PRESS/AFP via Getty Images)

A Shinkansen bullet train rail yard flooded by Typhoon Hagibis in Nagano, central Japan (Picture: KYODO/REUTERS)

Houses submerged after Typhoon Hagibis hit Ashikaga, north of Tokyo (Picture:Takuya Inaba/Kyodo News via AP)

Ruling party politician Fumio Kishida said the government would do its utmost in rescue operations and ensured those in shelters would be taken care of.

He acknowledged Japan’s power grids needed to be strengthened so people in disaster areas could get timely information.

‘So many risks remain, and it is a reality we must stay on guard,’ Kishida said. ‘We must do our utmost. In these times, a disaster can hit anytime.’

The typhoon’s aftermath has been categorised as a tropical storm.

The rugby union world cup match between Namibia and Canada, which had been scheduled to take place today in Kamaishi, northern Japan, was canceled as a precautionary measure, although organisers announced Japan would still play Scotland as scheduled this evening.

Stranded families rescued in Iwaki, Fukushima (Picture: Kyodo News via AP)

Members of the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force handle a flat-bottomed boat during relief operations in Shibata district (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

A Japan Self-Defense Force helicopter hovers above the submerged residential area in Nagano, central Japan (Picture: AP via Kyodo News)

All matches on Saturday had been canceled.

The typhoon disrupted a three-day weekend in Japan that included ‘Sports Day’ on Monday.

Qualifying for a Formula One race in Suzuka was pushed from Saturday to today.

The authorities warned Hagibis was as strong as the 1958 typhoon that hit the Tokyo region leaving more than 1,200 people dead and half a million houses flooded.

An evacuee is helped by Japan Self-Defense Forces members in Motomiya, Fukushima (Picture: AP/ Kyodo News)

A man stands in a flooded residential in Kawasaki (Picture: REUTERS)

description: Woman dropped 40 metres from rescue helicopter is among the 19 dead as the worst storm in 60 years, Typhoon Hagibis, hit Japan's Tokyo coast
